column4: are you sure you're not using public key authentication with password authentication disabled?
are you behind a router?
did you check ufw is not blocking 22?
just for testing purposes type sudo disable ufw (only for a couple moments) just so that we can insure its not ufw causing it
i disabled ufw aginn
what is the make and model of your router?
i would actually completely open your router up and just use IPTABLES to filter the traffic across your network
I have vonage voip connected to my linksys wrt54gs
what device.. the vonage device is also a firewall
completely disable firewall on your router and dmz your IP
ensure that you have spi firewall disabled on your router
Its the VDV21-VD
spi firewall? are you seeing that in the docs? I've never seen anything named spi firewall on the linksys
the only thing I can't turn off of the router's firewall is spi firewall
sorry, meant to say the only thing I can't turn off is Filter IDENT(Port 113)
ah, the problem was with the linksys router. As soon as I turned on dmz, it worked.
it might be called something different
now use IPTABLES to filter the traffic across your network, maybe even just get rid of that linksys and build your self a linux router
I got ufw back up now. Problem is I have other computers that I want to connect via ssh. If I fwd all the ports to this laptop then how am I going to connect to other pcs?
that's why i suggested that you build a linux router
for now though i would disable the spi firewall on the linux router and undo the dmz of your computer then just use port forwarding
what spi firewall?
there should be a setting in your router somewhere you should see it
